quiz.title: Physics Grade 11: Specific Heat Capacity
quiz.subtitle: Unit 7, Quiz 4: Conceptual Heat & Thermal Inertia
quiz.subject: Physics

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the property of 'Specific Heat Capacity'?
options: The energy required to raise the temperature of 1 kg of a substance by 1°C.
The total thermal energy contained within a substance at 100°C.
The speed at which heat moves through a specific material.
The temperature at which a substance changes phase from solid to liquid.
questions.explanation: Specific heat capacity is a measure of how much energy is needed to change the temperature of a specific amount of mass. It is a 'per kilogram' property.

questions.question: If you add the same amount of heat energy to equal masses of water and lead, why does the lead reach a much higher temperature?
options: Lead has a higher specific heat capacity than water.
Water molecules are physically larger and move slower.
Lead has a lower specific heat capacity, meaning it is less 'resistant' to temperature change.
Water reflects the heat while lead absorbs it.
questions.explanation: Substances with low specific heat capacities require very little energy to show a large increase in temperature (average kinetic energy).

questions.question: Water has a very high specific heat capacity. How does this affect the climate of cities located near the ocean?
options: Coastal cities experience extreme temperature swings every day.
The water acts as a thermal buffer, keeping temperatures more moderate and stable.
The water causes the air to heat up faster than in a desert.
Specific heat has no effect on local weather or climate.
questions.explanation: Because water requires a massive amount of energy to change temperature, it absorbs heat in the summer and releases it in the winter without changing its own temperature drastically.

questions.question: In the equation Q = mcΔT, what does the 'c' represent?
options: The speed of light
The total heat energy
Specific Heat Capacity
The change in temperature
questions.explanation: In thermodynamics, 'c' is the constant for specific heat capacity, unique to each substance.

questions.question: A substance with a high 'thermal inertia' would most likely have which property?
options: A very low boiling point
A high specific heat capacity
High thermal conductivity
A very low mass
questions.explanation: Thermal inertia refers to the resistance to temperature change. A high specific heat capacity provides this resistance.

questions.question: Why is water often used as a coolant in car engines?
options: It is the only liquid that does not expand when heated.
It can absorb a large amount of heat with only a small increase in its own temperature.
It is a better conductor than metal.
It has a lower density than other liquids.
questions.explanation: Water's high specific heat allows it to carry a lot of energy away from the engine without boiling immediately.

questions.question: Which of these is an intensive property (does not depend on the amount of matter present)?
options: Thermal Energy
Mass
Specific Heat Capacity
Total Heat Capacity
questions.explanation: Specific heat capacity is the same for 1 gram of water as it is for 1000 grams of water. It is a property of the material itself.

questions.question: What happens to the molecules of a substance with a low specific heat capacity when heat is added?
options: Their average kinetic energy increases rapidly.
They grow in size but do not move faster.
They absorb energy into vibrations without increasing speed.
They immediately stop moving.
questions.explanation: Low specific heat means most of the added energy goes directly into translational kinetic energy, which we measure as a rapid rise in temperature.

questions.question: If you double the mass of a substance but add the same amount of heat, what happens to the temperature change (ΔT)?
options: The temperature change is doubled.
The temperature change is halved.
The temperature change stays the same.
The temperature change becomes zero.
questions.explanation: According to Q = mcΔT, ΔT is inversely proportional to mass. Doubling the mass spreads the energy over more particles, resulting in half the temperature rise.

questions.question: Which material would likely be best for a heat sink in a computer (needs to absorb and dissipate heat quickly)?
options: A material with high specific heat and low conductivity.
A material with low specific heat and high conductivity.
Wood or plastic.
A material that expands significantly when heated.
questions.explanation: A heat sink needs to be able to transfer heat away (high conductivity) and change temperature easily to maintain a gradient (low specific heat).

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You have a deep conceptual grasp of thermal properties.
scoreMessages.70: Good work. Review the relationship between mass and temperature change.
scoreMessages.50: Keep practicing. Focus on why water is such a unique thermal substance.
